results.name: Number of iterations before prime(n) reaches 7 or 2 under x -> A007918(A138750(x)).
comment: As explained in A138751, the map x->A007918(A138750(x)) is a natural generalization of the Collatz map to primes.
The only even prime p=2 is the only fixed point of this map, and all odd primes seem to end up in the loop 7 -> 17 -> 11 -> 7, after a number of steps given in the present sequence.

(It might have been more natural to count the steps until a number is reached for the second time. Depending on which number among {2,7,11,17} is reached first, this would increase the value of a(n) by 1,3,2 resp. 1.)
link: Index entries for sequences related to 3x+1 (or Collatz) problem
example: a(1)=a(4)=0 since prime(1)=2 and prime(4)=7 are by definition the values at which counting ends.
a(primepi(4499221))=63337 according to G. Brougnard, cf. Link.
program: (PARI) A138752(n,c=0) = { if( n==1 & 7==n=prime(n), 0, until( 7==n=nextprime( if( n%3==2, ceil(n/2), 2*n )),c++);c)}
